awd_abstract_narration:
Free Space Optical (FSO) networks are increasingly of interest because of their ability to deliver very high data rates 'through the air'.  They are being applied to an expanding set of diverse application areas, e.g., satellite crosslinks and downlinks to earth and airborne platforms, communication among aircraft, metro short haul applications, telecom/wireless front and back haul, and datacenter networks, all of which are struggling to keep pace with the deluge of data that is now part of every enterprise. This project will organize and run a workshop with the goals of identifying the key research challenges, open problems and major opportunity areas associated with FSO.  The output of the workshop will help guide the future research investigations of the CISE and ENG communities.

Free space optical (FSO) communication networks are important because of the very high bit rates they can potentially deliver 'through the air'.  In addition to traditional application areas (e.g., satellite crosslinks and downlinks to earth and airborne platforms, communication among aircraft), a diverse set of new applications areas is emerging (e.g., metro short haul applications, telecom/wireless front and back haul, and datacenter networks).  These systems have been leveraging traditional telecom technologies, which are delivering programmable, high-bit rate, spectrally efficient transmission in ever-smaller form factors.  Beyond this, there is the emergence of new technologies (e.g. silicon nanophotonics, phased arrays, long-wavelength sources), advances in signal processing and interaction with the networking layer which may have the potential to enable a significant "leap" in FSO capabilities.  The workshop this project will run is therefore very timely; it will bring together a community covering both a wide array of application areas and new technologies to identify the major challenges and opportunities for FSO systems. The workshop output will be used to guide future research investigations within CISE and ENG communities.  The variety of FSO application areas to be discussed (e.g., indoor vs. outdoor, long vs. short range) also suggests considerable opportunity for technical cross-fertilization among diverse research groups.

por.por_cntn:
The main objectives of the workshop briefly stated were:

  1. Lay out state-of-the-art and challenges in free space optical communication/networks
  2. Bring together researchers and practitioners from academia, industry and gov. labs and agencies.
  3. Suggest research frontiers in channel and network modeling, hardware implementation, devices, system designs and network architectures.
  4. Examine possible architectures for Satellite cross-links and downlinks to earth and airborne platforms, communication among aircraft, metro short haul applications including back haul, and data center networks
  5. Articulate challenges in creating communication and network designs that deal with
    1. widely varying channel properties,
    2. lower cost systems, including nano-photonics and adaptive techniques
    3. Networking and systems that need more attention and new ideas that can accommodate a highly variable channel.
  1. Stimulate the research community into tackling the emerging hard problems in this space.

Important attributes affecting system/network designs and types of channels and degrees of challenges

Optical wireless communication systems have attributes not commonly found in wired communications. These are mostly channel effects plus the ability to reconfigure using beam steering. The latter opens up a degree of freedom to rearrange network topologies rapidly on demand adding tremendous flexibility to the routing layer (Layer 3) that at the moment is not fully exploited.  Areas that are unique to optical wireless networks that need attentions and unique research and developments are (Fig. 2):

  1. Pointing and tracking (PT).  In some case sub-micro radian accuracies are needed and in some areas the beams are subjected to random steering by atmospheric and fast platform dynamics.
  2. Link delay (D). Link delays ranges from sub-seconds to hours. The longer delays will surely render current Internet protocols extremely inefficient or not operational.
  3. Turbulence (T). This atmospheric and aircraft effects induces fading and beaming steering that need to be contended with in the network design. Atmospheric effects tend to be slow (1mS-100mS) but aircraft air flow dynamics may be as fast as 0.1mS for bow shocks.
  4. Weather attenuation (A).  For short range systems, there are possibilities to operate in poor weather such as rain, snow and fog at short range (<1Km). This is a very difficult channel that will likely a multi-layer network solution that is yet to be invented.
  5. Reconfiguration speed (RS). Reconfiguration speeds at the link and network layers can range from very fast (mS) to very long (hours). The very short reconfiguration abilities can be harnessed for new network architectures that are much better suited for these channels but they present serious engineering challenges as will be articulated in this report.
  6. Cost/HW-integration (C). To a large extent many physical layer mitigation techniques have been realized albeit often at very high costs. New technologies such as silicon photonics and low SWAP integrations will provide high performance and affordable terminals for ubiquitous deployments.
  7. Spatial dispersion (Dis). The underwater channel exhibit significant spatial dispersion as well as attenuations. New link and network topology designs are needed to provide networks with the right attributes for the applications mentioned.

These attributes are not all orthogonal and independent and must be considered jointly during research and system developments.  The following areas will need new research and developments:

  1. New technologies to reduce SWAP
  2. Turbulence mitigation
  3. Media Access Control
  4. Routing
  5. Transport layer protocol

Fast dynamic reconfiguration – capacity, routing, transport layer, etc 

Summary

Optical wireless networking is a new technology with plenty of application possibilities. Many significant system level questions need to be answered and network designs are at their infancies and in many cases sensible architecture features have yet to be invented. The dynamic and fast changing nature of the medium will require network protocols and control planes that react and adapt at much faster than current speeds. This is a rich area for network research. The following are some directions with potentially significant high leverages research: 

  1. Beam steering that allows rapid topology reconfiguration based on missions, sensing link state changes and traffic demand
  2. Dynamic link quality (turbulence) and potentially long delays requireing redesign of network architecture, particularly protocols
  3. Acquisition time that can be as fast as <1mS, with reconfiguration speed that is fast enough to track traffic trends and some atmospheric link degradations
  4. Algorithms that improve delay performance without detailed assumptions of channel and traffic statistics
  5. Use of cognitive techniques to provide prediction of optimum configuration for adaptation.
  6. Open air security to be incorporated in the network architecture at its conception.
